articles.headline: When Impact Investing Stays Local
articles.snippet: Philanthropic families find ways give back to the cities where their businesses started, rather than a seeking global cause.
articles.abstract: Philanthropic families find ways give back to the cities where their businesses started, rather than a seeking global cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: BY the mid-1990s, the Houghton family, whose wealth is derived from the glass and ceramic material manufacturer Corning, was into its sixth generation. Many of the cousins felt they had lost touch and were drifting away from the family.

articles.headline: Judges Rebuke Limits on Wiping Out Student Loan Debt
articles.snippet: Erasing student loans requires proof that paying the debt would cause “undue hardship,” and some judges think the rigid standard should be reconsidered.
articles.abstract: Erasing student loans requires proof that paying the debt would cause “undue hardship,” and some judges think the rigid standard should be reconsidered.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a typical day in her last job, Janet Roth left home at 4 a.m. each day and drove 40 miles to a tax preparation office in Glendale, Ariz. When she finally got back home, she had less than an hour before starting her 6 p.m. shift decorating cakes at Walmart. She worked until midnight, giving her just a few hours to sleep before starting all over again.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Appeal? G.O.P. Is Puzzled, but His Fans Aren’t
articles.snippet: Donald Trump has become the new starring attraction for the restless, conservative-minded voters who think the political process is in need of disruption.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump has become the new starring attraction for the restless, conservative-minded voters who think the political process is in need of disruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: LACONIA, N.H. — There are many, many things Donald Trump would like you to know about how he would run the country. As he told a standing-room-only crowd here the other night, turning America around would be a lot like running the Trump National Doral golf club in Miami, which he bought when it was in bankruptcy in 2012.

articles.headline: As Chattanooga Death Toll Rises, Mourning Deaths on Home Soil
articles.snippet: Portraits of the victims of the shooting in Chattanooga emerged as the death toll rose to five on Saturday.
articles.abstract: Portraits of the victims of the shooting in Chattanooga emerged as the death toll rose to five on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gunnery Sgt. Thomas Sullivan was in the Marine Corps for 18 years, survived truck bombs and a rain of mortars during one of the biggest assaults of the Iraq war, earned a Combat Action Ribbon and two Purple Hearts, and was expecting to retire soon. Instead he was ambushed on home soil, in a suburban Chattanooga, Tenn., office park.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps, Jess Bidgood and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: Public Enemy? At Home in Mexico, ‘El Chapo’ Is Folk Hero No. 1
articles.snippet: A daring break from a secure prison by the notorious cartel figure has enhanced his status as an outlaw folk hero in his home state and beyond.
articles.abstract: A daring break from a secure prison by the notorious cartel figure has enhanced his status as an outlaw folk hero in his home state and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULIACÁN, Mexico — When José Antonio Sevilla and his three brothers learned that the notorious drug trafficker known as El Chapo had escaped from prison, they jumped out of their chairs and shouted with glee.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Germany Risks Its Reputation With Idea of Greece Exiting Eurozone
articles.snippet: The suggestion that Greece might be better off leaving the eurozone — and the German leadership’s aggressive, punishing tone — could erode the trust Germany has built in Europe, some analysts say.
articles.abstract: The suggestion that Greece might be better off leaving the eurozone — and the German leadership’s aggressive, punishing tone — could erode the trust Germany has built in Europe, some analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — For decades, Germany saw its role as the financier and beneficiary of European unity, a combination of penance for the past and self-interest. The rest of the Continent came to rely on it as the country that could be trusted to keep its great experiment moving forward.

articles.headline: A Swedish Ad Campaign, for Kalles Kaviar, Tests the World’s Gag Reflex
articles.snippet: A series of Swedish commercials for a salty cod roe paste that only Swedes seem to appreciate can also serve as a whimsical study in global manners.
articles.abstract: A series of Swedish commercials for a salty cod roe paste that only Swedes seem to appreciate can also serve as a whimsical study in global manners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kalles Kaviar is Sweden’s answer to Marmite.

articles.headline: Coal Miners Struggle to Survive in an Industry Battered by Layoffs and Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Shrinking exports and America’s growing reliance on hydraulic fracturing and renewable energy have left coal producers in deep trouble.
articles.abstract: Shrinking exports and America’s growing reliance on hydraulic fracturing and renewable energy have left coal producers in deep trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAYNE, W.Va. — There is pain across the nation’s coal fields, but here in West Virginia, the disruption is particularly acute.

articles.headline: U.S. Agency Rules for Gays in Workplace Discrimination
articles.snippet: The decision by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sets the stage for litigation against discrimination based on sexual orientation.
articles.abstract: The decision by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sets the stage for litigation against discrimination based on sexual orientation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has ruled that workplace discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation is illegal under federal law, setting the stage for litigation aimed at striking down such practices.

articles.headline: Forecasters Expect a Strong Economy for the 2016 Presidential Election
articles.snippet: The economy, and how fast it’s changing, can matter a lot in presidential politics.
articles.abstract: The economy, and how fast it’s changing, can matter a lot in presidential politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to elections, fundamentals matter. A lot.

articles.headline: Federal Inquiry Scrutinizes Chattanooga Gunman’s Travel and Texts
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. was reviewing a text that the gunman, Mohammod Abdulazeez, sent hours before his rampage, and was expanding an inquiry into his 2014 trip to Jordan.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. was reviewing a text that the gunman, Mohammod Abdulazeez, sent hours before his rampage, and was expanding an inquiry into his 2014 trip to Jordan.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — The F.B.I. is reviewing a text message that the gunman who opened fire on two military facilities here sent to a friend hours before his rampage, a law enforcement official said Saturday. That text, which might provide insight into the gunman’s motivation, included a link to an Islamic verse saying, “Whosoever shows enmity to a friend of Mine, then I have declared war against him.”
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams, Michael S. Schmidt and Kenneth R. Rosen

articles.headline: Family Troubles Before Killings in Chattanooga
articles.snippet: Those who knew the family of Mohammod Abdulazeez, who the authorities say fatally shot four Marines and a Navy petty officer on Thursday in Chattanooga, Tenn., recalled a family that seemed to fit in. But problems existed out of neighbors’ sight.
articles.abstract: Those who knew the family of Mohammod Abdulazeez, who the authorities say fatally shot four Marines and a Navy petty officer on Thursday in Chattanooga, Tenn., recalled a family that seemed to fit in. But problems existed out of neighbors’ sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — It was a quiet spring night in East Tennessee when a police officer noticed the old gray Toyota Camry rolling slowly through downtown streets, swerving out of its lane and stopping for green lights.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Manny Fernandez

articles.headline: Donald Trump Says John McCain Is No War Hero, Setting Off Another Storm
articles.snippet: In Iowa, Mr. Trump disparaged Mr. McCain’s Vietnam War record, saying: “He’s not a war hero. He’s a war hero because he was captured. I like people who weren’t captured.”
articles.abstract: In Iowa, Mr. Trump disparaged Mr. McCain’s Vietnam War record, saying: “He’s not a war hero. He’s a war hero because he was captured. I like people who weren’t captured.”
articles.lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — Donald J. Trump has made his name in politics with provocative statements, but it was not until Saturday, after the flamboyant businessman turned presidential candidate belittled Senator John McCain’s war record, that many Republicans concluded that silence or equivocation about Mr. Trump’s incendiary rhetoric was inadequate.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Bill Cosby, in Deposition, Said Drugs and Fame Helped Him Seduce Women
articles.snippet: Mr. Cosby testified over four days of intense questioning 10 years ago at a Philadelphia hotel, where he defended himself in a deposition for a lawsuit filed by a young woman who accused him of drugging and molesting her.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cosby testified over four days of intense questioning 10 years ago at a Philadelphia hotel, where he defended himself in a deposition for a lawsuit filed by a young woman who accused him of drugging and molesting her.
articles.lead_paragraph: Read updates of Day 11 of the Bill Cosby trial.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Draws Scrappy Determination From a Tough, Combative Father
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton rarely talks publicly about her father, Hugh E. Rodham, who exerted a powerful, if sometimes bruising, influence on her life before he died in 1993.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton rarely talks publicly about her father, Hugh E. Rodham, who exerted a powerful, if sometimes bruising, influence on her life before he died in 1993.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a little girl, if Hillary Rodham forgot to screw the cap back on the toothpaste, her father would toss the tube out the bathroom window. She’d scurry around in the snow-covered evergreen bushes outside their suburban Chicago home to find it and return inside to brush her teeth, reminded, once again, of one of Hugh E. Rodham’s many rules.

articles.headline: Greeks Worry About Bailout’s Push for an Economic Overhaul
articles.snippet: Changes in the way Greece conducts business would be disruptive but could also help mend the country’s economy.
articles.abstract: Changes in the way Greece conducts business would be disruptive but could also help mend the country’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — For Greece, it’s the economic equivalent of the Big Bang.

articles.headline: Who Advises Candidate Trump? (Hint: His Name Is Donald)
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s latest fit of pique, about Senator John McCain’s reputation as a war hero, exposed the biggest vulnerability of Mr. Trump’s campaign for president.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s latest fit of pique, about Senator John McCain’s reputation as a war hero, exposed the biggest vulnerability of Mr. Trump’s campaign for president.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what passes for normal inside Donald J. Trump’s unorthodox campaign for president, he flew from Arkansas to Iowa on his Trump-emblazoned jet on Friday, arrived the next morning at a candidate forum without any prepared remarks and, wearing a bright red tie that evoked his days on “The Apprentice,” told the world exactly what he thought about Senator John McCain’s reputation as a war hero.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: As Beijing Becomes a Supercity, the Rapid Growth Brings Pains
articles.snippet: The new megalopolis, Jing-Jin-Ji, is to cover ground the size of Kansas and have a population about six times larger than the New York metropolitan area.
articles.abstract: The new megalopolis, Jing-Jin-Ji, is to cover ground the size of Kansas and have a population about six times larger than the New York metropolitan area.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANJIAO, China — Every morning at 5:30, Liu Desheng joins a dozen retirees waiting for the express bus to central Beijing from this small city in Hebei Province. They stand at the front of the line but never board, instead waiting as bus after bus pulls up, each picking up 50 people from the ever-lengthening line behind the retirees.

articles.headline: A Wizard at Prying Government Secrets From the Government
articles.snippet: Jason Leopold of Vice News uses an encyclopedic knowledge of the Freedom of Information Act to obtain tens of thousands of pages of government documents.
articles.abstract: Jason Leopold of Vice News uses an encyclopedic knowledge of the Freedom of Information Act to obtain tens of thousands of pages of government documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the reporter Jason Leopold gets ready to take on the United States government, he psychs himself up by listening to the heavy metal bands Slayer and Pantera.

articles.headline: Apple Waits as App Developers Study Who’s Buying Its Watch
articles.snippet: Facebook and other companies have struggled with how wearers of the device could have a good experience with their apps tailored to a small screen.
articles.abstract: Facebook and other companies have struggled with how wearers of the device could have a good experience with their apps tailored to a small screen.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the months surrounding the much-ballyhooed release of the Apple Watch, Apple managers courted Facebook in the hopes that the social networking giant would make a software application for the new gadget.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: A Light Bulb Goes On, Over the Mall
articles.snippet: Public lighting that dials into the Internet of Things could use billions of fixtures to collect data about things as diverse as traffic congestion and a shopper in the cereal aisle.
articles.abstract: Public lighting that dials into the Internet of Things could use billions of fixtures to collect data about things as diverse as traffic congestion and a shopper in the cereal aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the many promises of the Internet of Things — a network of Wi-Fi-connected devices and equipment managed with smartphones — is the automation of everyday life, whether finding a parking space or discovering a discounted blouse at the mall or lighting the streets when day shifts to dusk.

articles.headline: Laws Hinder Prosecutors in Charging G.M. Employees in Ignition Defect
articles.snippet: Prosecutors seeking to charge individuals over the ignition defect linked to 124 deaths are stymied by loopholes the auto industry helped create.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors seeking to charge individuals over the ignition defect linked to 124 deaths are stymied by loopholes the auto industry helped create.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the factory floor to the corporate suite, employees at General Motors saw indications of a deadly ignition defect and failed to disclose the problem to the government.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Windows 10 Signifies Microsoft’s Shift in Strategy
articles.snippet: Pressure from competitors has compelled the company to make the upgrade free and to find new ways to profit from some of its big moneymakers.
articles.abstract: Pressure from competitors has compelled the company to make the upgrade free and to find new ways to profit from some of its big moneymakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Next week, when Microsoft releases Windows 10, the latest version of the company’s operating system, the software will offer a mix of the familiar and new to the people who run earlier versions of it on more than 1.5 billion computers and other devices.

articles.headline: For G.O.P., Pope Francis’ Visit to Congress Comes With Tensions
articles.snippet: Pope Francis has forcefully staked out ideological ground opposite that of Speaker John A. Boehner and his Republican Party.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis has forcefully staked out ideological ground opposite that of Speaker John A. Boehner and his Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the Reading, Ohio, neighborhood where Speaker John A. Boehner grew up, nearly every house had two things on the wall: a crucifix and a photo of the pope. “You never ever expected to meet the pope,” said Jerry Vanden Eynden, a lifelong friend of Mr. Boehner’s. “In all of our minds, the pope was the closest thing to meeting God in person here on earth.”

articles.headline: Murder at Sea: Captured on Video, but Killers Go Free
articles.snippet: A video shows at least four unarmed men being gunned down in the water. Despite dozens of witnesses, the killings went unreported and remain a mystery.
articles.abstract: A video shows at least four unarmed men being gunned down in the water. Despite dozens of witnesses, the killings went unreported and remain a mystery.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHARJAH KHALID PORT, United Arab Emirates — The man bobbing in the sea raises his arms in a seeming sign of surrender before he is shot in the head. He floats face down as his blood stains the blue water.
